data.title: Joan Morgan
data.meta_description: Joan Morgan was one of the last surviving leading ladies of silent cinema and one of Britain’s first international film stars. She made her film debut in France as a child of 8 and over the next two
data.text:
Joan Morgan was one of the last surviving leading ladies of silent cinema and one of Britain’s first international film stars. She made her film debut in France as a child of 8 and over the next two decades went on to appear in several dozen films in England, America and South Africa, including the 1920 version of Little Dorrit.

Her acting career ended in the early Thirties, shortly after the advent of the talkies, though Morgan then became a successful scriptwriter, writing mainly for the “quota-quickies” — the low- budget British films that cinemas were required to show by law — and as a playwright and novelist.

Born in London in 1905, she was the daughter of the actress Evelyn Wood and of
